name: GJ 581
scenarioDescription:
The GJ 581 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 581 is a star with 0.31 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.29 times its radius. It is located 20.55 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 2 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

GJ 581 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 581 system


GJ 581 b

GJ 581 b was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 581 b is 15.8046 times the mass of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 581 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


GJ 581 c

GJ 581 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 581 c is 5.501399999999999 times the mass of Earth. At 5.501399999999999 Earth masses, GJ 581 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


GJ 581 e

GJ 581 e was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.03 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 581 e is 1.6854 times the mass of Earth. At 1.6854 Earth masses, GJ 581 e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system GJ 581, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by La Silla Observatory.
